citations.narrative:
Two dogs were identified during the inspection with matted hair. A female Burnese Mountain dog (Microchip number
2019) had mats under both ears. There were multiple mats under each ear that laid over each other. The dog did not
react to the mats being manipulated and there was no visible skin irritation. Additionally, a female Burnese Mountain dog
(microchip number 2010) also had thick mats under each of the ears. The dog did not react to the mats being manipulated
and there was no visible skin irritation.
Hair matting causes discomfort and can lead to sores and infections in dogs when not treated appropriately.
Correct by ensuring that all dogs receive preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats,
properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth.

The facility is not keeping/maintaining medical records for puppies that have left the facility. When puppies leave the
facility the cage cards that document the medical records for the puppies are discarded.
Failure to maintain the required records of vaccination and veterinary care to be provided to puppies in accordance with
the PVC can put current and future pups at risk of disease exposure or poor health.
Correct by ensuring that the medical records for dogs are kept and maintained by the dealer or exhibitor for at least 1 year
after the dog is euthanized or disposed of and for any period in excess of 1 year as necessary to comply with any
applicable Federal, State, or local law.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 12-October-2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
